newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - WALL STREET JOURNAL - DEC 10.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - WALL STREET JOURNAL - DEC 10.

text.p: The following stories were reported in Tuesday's edition of The Wall Street Journal:
- Technology stocks led a strong rebound in financial markets.
- Volkswagen chairman said he "deeply regrets" the company's long-running feud with General Motors over alleged industrial espionage.
- Digital Equipment was ordered to pay $5.3 million to a wowman in a carpal-tunnel disability case.
- Johnson Controls agreed to sell its plastic container operations to Viag Group for an estimated $650 million.
- Homestake Mining is counting on its proposed $2.16 billion stock acquisition of Santa Fe Pacific Gold to help return it to prominence among North American gold producers.
- Iraq will resume oil exports for the first time in more than six years.
- Time Warner is expected to announce it will spend as much as $450 million for a million new digital TV set-top boxes that offer more channels and thr Internet.
- Motorola mobile phone chief Staiano is leaving to run Iridium, a Motorola-backed staellite communications business that plans an IPO.
- Fidelity Magellan's former chief Jeffrey Vinik has been buying small-company stocks for his new hedge fund.
- Municipal-market participants say Miami's woes show that a lack of reliable data weakens the ability of credit rating agencies to alert investors to possible fiscal disasters.
- Creative BioMolecules will receive up to $123 million under a collaboration with Biogen to develop a drug that may help prevent kidney disease.
- The chip industry continued to show signs of recovery in November.
- Equifax said it plans to spin off its insurance service business from its core credit informations operations.
- Monsanto said it will cut 1,500 to 2,500 jobs after the planned spinoff of its chemical business.
- After hating bank stocks for most of last week, the stock market loves them again.
- The bond market on Monday shrugged off comments made last week by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan to stage a modest comeback.
